course.subject: ISOM
course.name: FinTech and Cryptoventures
course.description: This course provides an introduction to FinTech and cryptoventures. Topics include machine learning in financial analytics, Robo-advising, big data alpha models, algorithm trading and high-frequency trading, artificial intelligence, blockchain, cryptocurrencies, smart contracts, markets for smart contracts and applications of blockchain technologies in various finance areas. The class will use R to implement FinTech applications, and Solidity language to demonstrate smart contract development.
course.prerequisites: ISOM 2010 AND ISOM 2500

reviews.author: 就黎升仙
reviews.title: Online Mode
reviews.comment_content:
Blockchain and Cryptocurrency Technologies
Cryptocurrency
Enterprise Application
Smart Contract
Lightning Network
Solidity Essentials
Technical Analysis
Portfolio Selection and Algo Trading

P.S. Actually you can google everything and learn it yourself but I think the notes for smart contract and lightning network are in detailed.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor is willing to answer any question.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 5%
Assignment 10% (5% + 5%)
Group Project 15%
Exam 1 20%
Exam 2 20%
Exam 3 30%

Only show assignment, exam 1 and exam 2 scores

Grade: B

Grading is similar to other IS courses like 20% A range, 40% B range, 40% C range.
reviews.comment_workload: Group Project is the main workload because you need to do coding and write a 3-page report with teammates (max 4 people in a group).

reviews.author: helloust12345
reviews.title: interesting course
reviews.comment_content: Pretty interesting introduction to blockchain if you wanna know more about the topic. The first 60-70% of the course was relatively easier to understand. It might be a bit confusing or overwhelming at first, but I personally think it helps a lot if you're willing to rewatch the recordings. I find it easier to learn through the recordings as I can keep going back if there's a part Im confused about. It's also easier for you to jot notes as some content arent available on slides. The latter part is a bit more confusing and difficult to understand. Overall there's not a lot of content to go through
reviews.comment_teaching: The prof's accent may be hard to understand sometimes lol but she's very helpful and always stays behind to answer any questions. She always tries to recap and explain the concepts again to make sure we understand
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 5%
i feel like i wasnt too active throughout the sem lol, just occassionally answered qs in chat. And i think attendance isnt recorded as well

Assignment 10% (5% + 5%)
Assms are pretty easy, the prof spends a lssn talking about each assm and teaches you how to do it lol. Took me probably an hour for each assm. Got full marks for both

Group Project 15%
I think the project was quite confusing for me. It requires you to develop the code for sth blockchain/smart contract related but not much of the course is really about coding. So if you or your teammates dont have any programming background its quite challenging. The deliverables are the code and the 2(?) page report. The report is really simple, its just the coding part thats challenging. For me and my group, I feel like we didnt really spend too much time on the project and we chose a relatively simpler topic, but I guess we did ok, dont know what grade we got though

3 exams 20% each
The topics for the first two exams are pretty easy, and because the prof spends a lot of time repeatedly explaining the concepts, in the end the amount of content isnt that much. Theres not a lot of stuff to study and the exam is just a few mc questions plus one or two short qs, really simplen format. The last exam was more challenging, and the topics were a bit confusing to me.
I was just slightly above mean for the first two exams, didnt receive the grading for the last exam but i feel like i didnt do well

I felt like I was going to get a B range but surprisingly got an A so i was pretty happy with it lol
reviews.comment_workload: Actually pretty light workload. Assms were really simple and fast to complete. For the exams, I usually study about 2-3 days before the exam (I usually listen during class or would watch the recordings afterwards). As for the project it depends, but it was ok for me
